awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Auditing Critical Dependencies Between Online Media Platforms
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will audit the dependencies between major online media platforms, with a focus on major search engines, and investigate the extent to which they rely on content from social media platforms.  In recent years, the web has centralized around a small number of mega-platforms that attract the bulk of people's attention and the majority of content. Social media and search engines in particular dominate people's online time, and serve as de-facto "homepages" for many users. As these media platforms have grown to prominence, so too have concerns about their power to create and shape online spaces. All of the large online platforms use socio-technical algorithms to rank, filter, recommend, and moderate content, thus privileging some information at the expense of other information. Although mass media has always functioned this way, the novel concern is that the algorithms that implement these processes are opaque, making them difficult to understand, disintermediate, or contest. Algorithm auditing has emerged as a powerful approach to increase transparency and accountability around "black-box" systems, but the vast majority of existing audits fail to grapple with the dependencies between major online media platforms.
 
This project aims to answer several high-level questions, including: What fraction of search results link to social media? What social media platforms and authors appear in search results? How do links to social media vary by query? Are results for social media personalized? Do links to social media increase content diversity, or are they a vehicle for misinformation? With respect to simultaneous audits of search engines versus YouTube and Twitter, more specific questions will be investigated about how the algorithms on the social media sites (such as "like" recommendations and trending topics or videos) influence search results. Further, because Google Search and Bing both integrate specialized search components from Twitter and YouTube, simultaneous audits will jointly investigate how the algorithms on these pairs of platforms interact. To conduct these algorithm audits, hybrid techniques will combine carefully controlled experiments from the vantage point of real users with simulated online identities created by the auditor. This allows answering questions about the impact of algorithmic curation, as well as revealing some of its underlying causes. One major challenge when auditing online platforms is achieving ecological validity. Here, this means selecting queries that are representative of those executed by real people. To address this challenge, the research will leverage a unique dataset of Google Search queries from a panel of over 350 participants. This set of queries will be expanded with additional terms curated from other sources, and queries will be diversified using autocomplete suggestions. The results of this new algorithm audit methodology will be useful to the general public, strengthening their media literacy, as well as to the designers of the platforms themselves.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There is a growing body of work that uses algorithm auditing approaches to critically assess the systems deployed by large online platforms. These studies are motivated by ongoing concerns about the power of large online platforms to influence individual and collective behaviors, expose people to problematic content, and ultimately harm society.

The research conducted under this grant aims to broaden and deepen the field of algorithm auditing. To broaden the field, we examine dependencies between large online platforms, such as Google Search, YouTube, and Twitter. Although all of these platforms have been studied before, they have typically been examined in isolation. Unfortunately, this ignores the systematic dependencies between these platforms, which challenge our conceptions of their design and impact. For example, in the research funded under this grant, we investigated how the design of Google Search results promote link to YouTube videos over other, relevant content. Similarly, we examined how views of videos from problematic channels on YouTube often arrive at those videos from links on social media, as opposed to algorithmic recommendations on YouTube itself.

To deepen the field, we move beyond powerful, but limited, controlled experimental methodologies towards ecologically-valid methods that utilize observational trace data from real people. For example, we use observational data from demographically-representative panels of US residents to examine the usage of Google Search during major American elections, and compare this to panelists overall web browsing behavior. Using statistical approaches to control for confounding variables, we demonstrate how ecological data and pseudo-experimental techniques can be combined to reach powerful conclusions about the operation of large online platforms.

Intellectual Merit: The results of this research were published in well-regarded general audience journals (Nature, Science Advances) and computer science venues (ICWSM). Our study of engagement with Google Search results received a Best Paper award at ICWSM 2023.

Broadly speaking, the measurement methods we have pioneered when conducting research under this grant are raising the bar for field of computational social science. We have shown that ecologically- and demographically-valid online trace data can be collected at large-scale from consenting participants, and that this data yields broad insights into online life in general, and the implications of the design of major online platforms platforms on individual behavior in particular. The results of our research motivate the development of new scientific infrastructures, such as the NSF-funded National Internet Observatory, that will enable more scientists to conduct and replicate studies on the online life of US residents. 

Broader Impacts: Work funded under this grant has received significant media coverage. For example, our study of YouTube was covered by the New York Times and the Washington Post. This coverage helps educate the public about consequential issues concerning large online platforms, and speaks to ongoing debates about how to make large online platforms more transparent and accountable for content moderation issues.
